cluster_relations.rel_desc: The bloody hook is implied to be the same hook that served as the criminalâ€™s hand.
cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject and object refer to the same underlying physical object or token, possibly inferred rather than explicitly stated.

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: after the scratching and fear build-up
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: NarrativeFunction: proof that the Hook Man was present

remarks: Slightly inferential; text does not explicitly state it is the same hook.
Slightly inferential; text does not explicitly state it is the same hook.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The truth behind the stories corresponds to factual (verifiable) aspects of those stories.
cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject stands in a correspondence relation to the object, typically aligning or matching it in meaning or truth-value, without strict identity of reference.

args.justification: The relation between 'truth behind the stories' and 'fact' is one of semantic or epistemic correspondence, not strict identity of referents. While the existing rel_cls 'correspondence_relation' is appropriate, mapping the broad rel_cls_group to 'IDENTITY' overstates equivalence. Using 'ASSOCIATION' better captures that the subject aligns with or is grounded in the object without being literally the same entity.
args.remark: Adjusted rel_cls_group from IDENTITY to ASSOCIATION to distinguish correspondence from strict equivalence.

executed_decisions.justification: The relation between 'truth behind the stories' and 'fact' is one of semantic or epistemic correspondence, not strict identity of referents. While the existing rel_cls 'correspondence_relation' is appropriate, mapping the broad rel_cls_group to 'IDENTITY' overstates equivalence. Using 'ASSOCIATION' better captures that the subject aligns with or is grounded in the object without being literally the same entity.
executed_decisions.remark: Adjusted rel_cls_group from IDENTITY to ASSOCIATION to distinguish correspondence from strict equivalence.
